I am barmaid at the Duke of York, Waterloo Road—on March 29th, after two p.m., the prisoner came in for a small lemon, price twopence—he gave me a five-shilling piece—I put it in the till—there was no other crown there—I gave him the change and he left—I left the bar about three o'clock, and Mr. Hilliard sent up to me—I went down, and he showed me a crown piece—I noticed that the prisoner had an impediment in his speech—I was sent for to the station on the 31st, and saw a man being locked up who I recognised—I was afterwards sent for to the station, and picked the prisoner out from other men—I have no doubt of him—I recognised him apart from the impediment in his speech.

AUGUSTUS HILLIARD . I am manager of this public-house—on March 29th, between two and three p.m., I found a crown piece in the till, and only one—that was after Perry went upstairs—the till would be closed on her leaving the bar—I sent for her and showed it to her, and after
wards handed it to Lizall—this is it.

WALTER ALEXANDER HUSK . I keep the New Bridge Street House, Westminster—on March 31st, about four p.m., the prisoner came in for a a small lemon, price twopence—he gave me this bad five-shilling piece—I said, "Do you know what you gave me"—he said, "Yes; a five-shilling piece"—I said, "It is a bad one"—he said, "Don't thumb it"—I sent for a constable and gave him in custody, and broke the coin in pieces—the prisoner saw that—he said nothing—he was perfectly sober—the lemon is the usual thing to call for when bad money is passed.

WALTER LIZALL (Police Serjeant, L). On March 31st I was called to the New Bridge House and found the prisoner in the bar—Mr. Huss said he had tendered a bad five-shilling piece—he said, "What! Do you think I should do that with two constables outside?"—I searched him, and found one shilling and threepence in copper—I took him to the station, after which the other charge was mentioned, and Miss Perry was sent for—she picked him out of eight others—the public-houses are about a quarter of a mile apart.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am inspector of coin to Her Majesty's Mint—these coins are both counterfeit, but from different molds.
Prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "I own to uttering the first, but I did not know it was bad. The second I know nothing about. I do not know the man; I have a witness as to that."

Prisoner's defence: You know men are liable to get drunk. I thought the coin was good, but was given in charge. When I was at the station the first witness saw me between two constables, and when she came to identify me she said, "That is the man "Why did she not identify me in the street? There are plenty of people in the street like me.

GUILTY —
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

343.
JOSEPH WINNING (19)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

FLORENCE HILBERT . I am a draper with my sister at 136, Mintone Road, Wimbledon—on March 25th the prisoner came in for a 2 1/2 d. handker
chief and gave me this crown—I gave it to my sister—she went out of the shop and I wanted to detain the prisoner—I kept him in conversation—I wrapped the handkerchief up, but be went out before my sister came back, and ran away without waiting for his change or the handkerchief—when my sister came back I gave his description to the police—I after
wards picked him out from twelve others—I am sure he is the same boy—he never came back for his change.

ANNIE HILBERT . I am sister to the last witness—on March 25th I came into the shop and saw a lad—I am not quite certain of the prisoner—I took the five-shilling piece to get change—I saw the prisoner after
wards with four others at the Police-court—I was not certain; but I thought he was the boy.
ROBERT WILLIAMSON (Detective Officer). On March 25th Florence Hilbert gave me a description—I circulated it among the police—she also gave me a crown piece.

FLORENCE DUCHAL . I assist my father, who keeps a fancy shop at 40, North Road, Battersea—about 7.30 one evening the prisoner, to the best of my belief, came in for a threepenny mouth organ, and gave me a bad five-shilling piece—my mother came in—I passed it to her—she said it was bad—the boy said, "Oh, is it?" and picked it up and walked out—I gave information—we had two bad pieces before that—Carter, the constable, has them—my father went to the station—I was sent for, and picked the prisoner out from about twelve others.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. This was about seven o'clock—it was later than 6.30—I cannot say whether it was past seven.
CAROLINE DUCHAL . I am the mother of the last witness—she showed me a five-shilling piece—I took it in my hand—it was light and greasy, and I thought it was bad—I did not identity the prisoner.

WILLIAM HEAD (Detective Officer). I received some information and a description—on the morning of April 7th I saw the prisoner—these two shops are some two miles apart—I said "I am a police officer, and I shall take you for passing counterfeit coin"—I searched him and found nineteen shillings in silver, and three pence in copper, but no bad money—there were three half-crowns and three sixpences—I took him to the station—he was identified in the evening by the two witnesses—he made no reply to the other charge.
Cross-examined. There is a window in the inspectors office, but the witnesses did not go in there.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am inspector of coin to Her Majesty's Mint—this crown is counterfeit.

344.
RICHARD BANKS (28)
, Feloniously uttering counterfeit coin.

JOHN CARTER (234 V). On March 26th I was on point duty in Battersea about 6.30 and saw the prisoner looking into the shops in a suspicious manner with Webb (see page 658)—I kept them under observation—they got to the corner of Cairns Road, when Blinks pulled something like paper, about the size of his fist, out of his pocket, took something from it and handed it to Webb—I walked along on the other side—they turned up a road in the dark and I lost sight of them—I walked along the Northgate Road and received some information—I saw Banks looking into Mr. Piper's shop window at 19, Northgate Road—I went to the shop door and said, "Who wants me?"—Banks looked at me and ran away as hard as he could—Mr. Piper and Webb were struggling in the shop—I arrested Webb and gave Banks' description to Serjeant Windsor—I picked him out from twelve others on the night of Good Friday—I have no doubt about him.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I did not see you through the small window of the inspector's office—that is Webb (pointing to him).
Re-examined. I received a counterfeit coin from Piper and one shilling from Webb—there in a yard at the station—I never saw the prisoner from the time I first saw him till I picked him out.

ETHEL PIPER . I am a fancy draper with my father, at 19, Northgate Road, Battersea—on March 26th Webb came in "and gave me a bad five-shilling piece—I gave it to my father, who locked the door—he had a struggle with Webb, who was handed over to the police—that is Webb (pointing to the prisoner)—I did not see the prisoner.

GEORGE PIPER . I am father of the last witness—on March 26th Webb came in and put down a five-shilling piece—I locked the door and gave a signal—Webb asked me to look outside to see his father—I looked out and saw the prisoner Banks, to the best of my belief, and I afterwards picked him out from five others at the station—I believe he is the man, but I was struggling with Webb at the time.
Cross-examined. I said that I would not swear positively to you, as I only saw your side face—I saw a man outside before the policeman came.

WILLIAM STEPHENS (Detective V). In April last I was observing the prisoner's stable at Shelwood Road, Battersea—Greenwood and Willing went there and remained there a short time and came away—they noticed that we were following them and ran away—I saw Banks that day.

SARAH JANE WATSON . I am in the employ of the Welford Dairy Co., at Streatham—on April 4th, between five and six p.m., the youth Green
wood (see page 658) came in for two eggs, and put a five-shilling piece on the counter—I picked it up and did not like the look of it—I took it to the secretary, Mr. Renals—I did not notice anybody outside—I saw a man go by, but I cannot recognise him.

ANNIE RENALS . I am the wife of the secretary of the Welford (Surrey) Dairy Company—on April 4th I saw Greenwood in the shop, and through the open door I saw Banks and recognised him—Greenwood was given into custody—I saw Banks again on April 7th with eight or nine others, and picked him out at once—I have no doubt he is the man.

Cross-examined. That was last Friday week—it was not on the Thursday before Good Friday—I had no more doubt about picking you out than I should have had in picking out my own husband—it was not in the passage—there is no passage—I was not told to identify you.

JOHN WINDSOR (Detective V). I received a description from Carter, and arrested the prisoner in Latimer Road—it was 10 a.m.—he was driving a pony in a costermonger's cart—I said, "I am going to search you," and told him to get out—I took some good money from his pocket—I said, "I shall take you to the station"—he said, "What for?"—I said, "On suspicion of uttering"—he was placed with others and identi
fied—Carter had previously given a description, and I told him to go at seven o'clock—there is no truth in the statement that the lads were pointed out by the police or that the witnesses could see through a window.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am inspector of coin to Her Majesty's Mint—these coins are both bad and from different moulds—it is the custom of people engaged in coining to wrap the coins up in paper.

Prisoner's defence: Windsor stopped me and looked me to the station—I stopped there a long time, but there was nobody to identify me—I was charged with a man named Webb, but I do not know him—I never saw him in my life—I was simply taken on suspicion—I don't know where the shops are—she said she did not know whether I was the man, but when she got into the witness-box she said I was—I was never near that shop.

GUILTY .—He then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of feloniously uttering coin on December 12th, 1892, and six oilier convictions were proved against him and he had been twice sentenced to penal servitude.—
Seven Years Penal Servitude.

345.
HARRY CLEAVER (16)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin, MR. PARTRIDGE Prosecuted.

LILY WOOD . I assist Mrs. Markham, a fancy draper, of 40, West Hill, Wandsworth—on March 21st I served the prisoner with a handkerchief, price twopence—he gave me a four-shilling piece—it did not ring and I

showed it to Mrs. Markham, who said to the prisoner, "Is it a good coin?"—he said nothing, but laughed—she went outside with the coin—he went to the door and stood on the step and said, "The lady has gone a long time; I wonder where she has gone to," and walked away without the handkerchief and without his change—I afterwards identified him at the station from a great many other boys.

MRS. MARKHAM. I keep this shop—the last witness handed me a four-shilling piece—I saw a person in die shop—I cannot swear to the prisoner—I said, "I do not think this is good"—he made no reply—I took it to my next-door neighbour, got it tested, came back, and he had gone—he never came back for his change.

WILLIAM STEPHENS (Detective, V). I received a description which was circulated by the police, in consequence of which I arrested the prisoner in Hackney Road on April 7th—I said, "I am going to take you to the Police-station"—he said, "What for?"—I told him the charge—he said, "If I am identified I shall have to put up with it"—he was charged, and made no answer.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am inspector of coin at the Mint—this double florin is bad.

The Prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "When Detective Stephens stopped me he did not tell me what it was for at seven at night. When the witness pointed me out she said, 'It looks like him.' I did not tell Stephens that if I was identified I must put up with it."

GUILTY .— The Detective stated that he had been twice summarily con
victed and was connected with the same gang as Webb, Greenwood, and Winning.—
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

346.
HENRY LOFTHOUSE (21)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

NELLY ROSE LASCELLES . I am assistant at the bar of a tavern in the Waterloo Road—on April 5th, between ten and eleven p.m, I served the prisoner—he was with two others—he gave me a good shilling, and I gave him the change—a few minutes afterwards he paid for more drink with a florin—I placed it in the bottom row and gave him the change—the barman spoke to me—I pointed it out to him and he tried it—the prisoner was still in the bar—the barman handed it to my husband about six persons serve in the bar—I am sure he is the man as passed the shilling—I picked him out the same night at the station from eight other men.
The Prisoner. I did not tender the florin, it was a penny.

ROBERT HORNE . I am barman at the Victoria Tavern—on April 5th about 10.45 p.m., the prisoner came in with two others—he called for some ale, and gave me a shilling—I gave him the change—I afterwards served him with more liquor—he tendered me a florin—I found it was bad, and mentioned it to him, and said, "This is a bad one"—he took it from his pocket—he had other money in his hand, which he rattled before he took the money from his pocket—I spoke to Miss Lascelles, who pointed out this coin on the shelf—I tried it with aqua fortis—the other two men went out—the prisoner said that he would go and find them.
Cross-examined. You did not pay with the penny, it was with a florin.
LEONARD BARRETT LASCELLES . I am manager of the Victoria Tavern—on April 5th the prisoner was pointed out to me—I followed him and gave him into custody.

JAMES FORD (Police Inspector L). On April 5th—I found the prisoner detained by Mr. King and Mr. Lascelles—he said, "I know nothing about it; they have made a mistake"—he was taken to the station and charged—he said, "This is the second case you have against me"—I found on him 1s. 5 1/2 d. in bronze—Mr. King gave me this coin.
Cross-examined. I went to Myers, where you worked, and I found that you were there four years, and bore a good character up to September 29th last, since when you have been pushing a barrow.

ROBERT HORNE (re-examined). The man who tendered the florin to me was in the private bar—Miss Lascelles pointed him out to me, and I recognised him as the man who tendered the money to me—Mr. Lascelles followed him out—he went out by himself.
LEONARD BARRETT LASCELLES (re-examined). I followed the prisoner out and kept my eye on him—he was alone—he had" no opportunity of passing anything to anybody.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . This coin is counterfeit.
The Prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "I know nothing about it. Several others were there."
NELLY ROSE LASCELLES (re-examined). There are seven bars.
NOT GUILTY .

347.
GEORGE GREENWOOD** (16),
PLEADED GUILTY to
unlaw
fully uttering counterfeit coin.—
Judgment respited.

348.
GEORGE WEBB (17)
, To unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin. (The police stated that he had been once convicted and lived in the same lodging as Greenwood).—
Judgment respited.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

349.
JOHN SERVICE (42)
, to Unlawfully obtaining £23 15s., £95, and £47 10s. from
William Jackman by false pretences; also to three indictments for
forging and uttering bills of exchange for £50 and £100 with intent to defraud. He received a good character, but the prosecution stated that the forged bills between April and December amounted to about £1,000.—
Seven Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

350.
GRACE SIMMONS (20)
, to feloniously forging and uttering cheques for £3, £2, £2, £2, with intent to defraud.—
To enter into recognizances to come up for judgment when called upon.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.] And

(351)
FRANCIS HENNELL (40)
, To unlawfully obtaining £1, 10s., 1s., 1s., by false pretences, having been convicted of a like offence at Clerkenwell on August 29th, 1894.—
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

352.
FREDERICK COOK (19)
, Stealing three bags of coffee, the property of
Arthur James Humphrey and others.
WILLIAM DONALDSON . I live in Mary Street, Whitechapel—I am a master carman and I occasionally employed the prisoner and he became acquainted with my business—Owen Neal was in my employ on April
2nd and is now—it was his duty as carman to take the warrants and delivery orders and receive the goods for me to deliver.

OWEN NEAL . I am sixteen years old and live at 8, New Square, Minories—I am employed by Mr. Donaldson—on April 2nd I was driving a covered van—I was given lists to collect goods at Cotton's Wharf and other places—the prisoner, whom I knew, got on the van—he asked where I was going—f toil him to Cotton's, Wharf—he said, "Show me your orders"—I did so—I had to receive goods—he gave them back to me and I put them in my pocket—he got down before the van reached the wharf—at the wharf I handed in my orders, which were for eight bags of coffee, to the clerk in the office—I received those bags and signed for them—the prisoner came and asked me where I was going—I told him I was going to deliver five bags of coffee—when I got to South Bermondsey the eight bags were quite safe—I delivered five, and took three to Mr. Donaldson's office.

BALDWIN COOMBS . I know Neal as Mr. Donaldson's car-boy—on April 2nd he came to Cotton's Wharf for some coffee which was lying there—he lodged the necessary orders for eight bags—three were for Mr. Donaldson—the prisoner lodged this slip, for three bags, with Donaldson's stamp on it—I put it on the shelf for delivery to Nicholls.

JOHN BROAD NICHOLLS . I am under-delivery foreman at Cotton's wharf—on April 2nd, about 1.30, the prisoner came and asked if I was calling for Donaldsons—after taking the order out of the office, which was my duty, I said, "Yes; where is your van?"—he said, "Round the corner"—I said, "Bring it round here"—he brought a truck—I said, "This is rather a funny sort of van"—he said, "This is a truck, but I am Donaldson"—I gave up the three bags referred to in the order, and he went to the office and signed for them in the delivery book, and left the warrant—we had received the order for delivery to Donald
son on the Friday—I had lost the list of the deliveries between Donald
son's place and Fenchurch Street on the Tuesday.

JOSEPH PRUCE . I am junior clerk at Cotton's Wharf—I was present when Nicholls gave three bags of coffee to the prisoner—I gave his order to pass the goods out of the warehouse—the word "van," which was on it, has been altered to "truck"—I saw the receipt signed for the goods in this book in the name of "F. Jones," and I gave the person this ticket—I do not know the prisoner.

THOMAS CUCACK . I am gate-keeper at Cotton's Wharf—on March 2nd, about 1.30, I passed out a man who gave me this paper—he had three bags of coffee on a truck—I cannot swear to the prisoner—it was a man like him, but I looked more at the pass.

HENRY FITZGERALD (Detective Officer). Having received information I went to the Swan public-house, Whitechapel, with Nicholls who pointed out the prisoner, who was with eight or nine men there—I told him the charge—he said, "Where is your warrant?"—I said, "A warrant is not necessary in this case"—he said, "Oh, very well. I suppose I must go with you"—when charged at the station he made no reply.
The Prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "On Saturday week I was in the Swan, when the detective said he wanted me. I know nothing about it."
Prisoner's defence: I was not there. I am innocent of the crime.

GUILTY .—
Six Months' Hard Labour.

353.
JOHN UPTON (43)
, Committing an act of gross indecency with a person unknown.
NOT GUILTY .

354.
WILLIAM WEBB (26),
PLEADED GUILTY to
breaking and entering two churches and stealing therein, having been previously con
victed of the like and other offences.—
Four Years' Penal Servitude.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, MAY 16TH, 1898.
